entry.title: Selective Data Transition: HCM migration to the cloud
entry.content:
The private cloud edition of SAP HCM¸ which to a large extent reflects enhancement package 8, has been available since the 2022 release of S/4HANA 2022. It offers several innovations, especially in the Fiori user experience and performance. SAP HCM for S/4HANA is the successor solution to SAP HCM for ECC and can be used until 2040 at the earliest, while support for the existing HCM on ECC solution ends in 2027.  It’s important to note again at this point that customers must complete their selective data transformation (SDT) project well before the end of the maintenance support. And this is a major reason for the sense of urgency surrounding HCM transformations.

Customers who have opted for extended maintenance have more time to complete their transformation, as support won’t end until 2030. However, those who have already moved to S/4HANA with the compatibility mode should act quickly: the right to use it expires at the end of 2025. Lastly, for RISE customers, user rights terminate at the end of 2030.

Discontinued and new functions

Some of the functionalities currently in HCM may be succeeded by new functions in the S/4HANA version. This is a further urgency factor, as customers may need to plan, budget and implement a pre-project before the actual S/4HANA transition to deal with the discontinued and new functions. That’s why it’s important for customers to review and deal with these, as well as any organizational and process changes, long before their actual S/4HANA transition. The closer customers get to the end of maintenance, the harder it will be to plan and implement pre-projects – and especially to find an implementation partner to help with the work.

What are the target scenarios to consider in the transition to HCM on S/4HANA or to SuccessFactors? The bulk of the HCM innovations are reflected in SAP’s SuccessFactors public cloud solution. Many customers need more time to move to S/4HANA – so SAP has made an on-premises solution temporarily available as a result.  However, the enhancements in this solution will be limited to localized legal requirements like payroll and social insurance. The main focus of the innovations will be within the SuccessFactors solution.

Choosing between HCM on S/4HANA and SuccessFactors

Looking at SuccessFactors, why would a customer choose S/4HANA over SuccessFactors? The main reason is – again – the maintenance deadlines. For most legacy HCM customers, S/4HANA is the better choice for the simple reason that the implementation time will be much faster. They can keep their own customizations, processes, and developments, while with SuccessFactors they’ll have to recreate their architecture and redesign their processes, generating higher costs. With S/4HANA they are securing current investments – even though they may be missing out on the innovations in SuccessFactors.

Database volume reduction options

One option for customers is to simply convert their legacy HCM solution to S/4HANA. The key thing to remember here is that the simplification items – such as managers’ desktop, cost planning, recruiting and training management – are not available in S/4HANA and will be replaced with alternative solutions. For that reason, it doesn’t make sense for customers to keep obsolete data from these items in their new S/4HANA system. Instead, they only need migrate the really important applications, data and functionalities – the basis of SDT. There are cost and efficiency benefits to starting with a lean and clean S/4HANA system while significantly reducing the size of their database.

SDT is also beneficial in other ways. Prior to a transition, customers usually start with specific selection criteria, such as employee numbers, as some staff may have left the company. Probably the most important criterion is the time slice function. Many organizations have 30 years or more of payroll history in their HCM systems, whereas much of that data is unnecessary on the new system. Around 5-7 years of data is about average to enable companies to make retroactive calculations for benefit plans or other purposes. The time slice significantly reduces the size of the future S/4HANA database, even by as much as 50%.

SDT for complex, integrated systems

The SDT approach for customers with very complex HCM systems – especially when the HCM system is integrated into the ERP system – is often greenfield for the financial and controlling data. Conversely, with HCM they choose the brownfield approach because they want to protect all of the significant development investments they’ve made over the years. The greenfield and brownfield approaches can be combined into a single project, while applying SDT precepts to the HCM data. As we saw earlier, a 30-year historical database is too much for most companies, so they can limit the transitioned data to about 5-7 years and make the database much leaner.

It's important to emphasize here that SAP and its SDT Engagement partners always take local regulations into account – for example, 5 to 7 years of payroll data may be too little in some geographies. In addition, they will always align the historical HCM data to the new financial and controlling structure, as cost center information may change and need to be adapted. Having said that, SAP and its SDT Engagement partners have the tools, services, and flexibility to offer this mapping service to customers as an additional sub-project.

SuccessFactors ECP

A further option for organizations wishing to transition is a move to SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (ECP). In this case, the customer would only migrate the relevant payroll data from their HCM system to the ECP cloud. This is also a form of SDT as the migration only applies to data based on one application. With migration to ECP, time slice is the most common SDT criterion, as it enables customers to preserve only the last few years of history for legal or audit reasons or for retroactive calculations.

How the project works

These SuccessFactors or HCM migrations are structured similarly to a normal IT project. We should emphasize here that it’s crucial to leave enough time for testing – and even to carry out the migration two or three times to be sure everything is running smoothly.

 

Phases or big bang?

With ERP transitions, go-live is often phased as organizations take one company or division live first and iron out any issues, then move on to the next phase. However, HCM differs as it requires highly consistent data, so the big bang approach is preferable. As we saw earlier, testing beforehand is the key. Customers need to be sure everything is working properly when there are no employees connected to the system, i.e. on the weekend before go-live.

Project duration and timing

The experience of SAP and its SDT Engagement partners shows that 9 to 12 months is about average if the HCM system is integrated with ERP. If HCM is standalone, the project can take as little as 6 to 9 months. Another difference from ERP projects is the timing. ERP migrations are often performed at the end of the financial year, yet this is the busiest time for HR professionals as they have a heavy workload with payroll and social insurance calculations. This is also the time that SAP brings out special support updates (so-called Christmas packages). Customers embarking on an SDT initiative can (and should) implement support packages during the project but SAP and its SDT Engagement partners recommend completing this prior to the dry-run and go-live phases.

Preparatory tasks to complete prior to project kick-off

There are a few things customers can do before the project gets started. The first is to deal with the simplification items detected by the readiness check, as these will not be available in the new system. The second key task is defining which data customers want to transfer or leave behind. The third is to check third-party tools, which are often used by the HR department. This is a crucial point because not all of them support HCM on S/4HANA. Customers should therefore contact the suppliers to ask if the tools are S/4HANA-compatible and whether there’s any adjustments they need to make. Organizations may also find that it is necessary to review the budget, resource, and implementation planning again, especially if there are functions and/or tools not supported by, or available on, the new system. Last but not least, customers should review their Fiori front-end strategy, especially as some HR systems are used by employees on a daily basis.

 

Top three tasks for customers prior to the SDT project

Next steps

The first thing customers can do now is to set up the appropriate HR IT strategy and define the system landscape (S/4HANA on-premises, which is secured at least until the end of 2040, SuccessFactors with its new functions, and HCM on S/4HANA). Customers should decide whether to go for a private or public cloud and define a rough timeline. It’s important to circle back with ERP colleagues too, as changes to data like company codes need to be reflected in the HCM system too. They can carry out a readiness check to ascertain the project duration and budget. A crucial step for customers to take now is to contact implementation partners and choose one in good time to help them with the SDT project. These specialists are already in high demand now, so this is a good place for potential customers to start!

Discover more: For more detailed information, watch the webinar recording of "SDT: How to Deal with the SAP Suite Solutions? Focus: HCM" and learn how Selective Data Transition enables not just a technical migration – but a holistic transformation that secures your HR data, streamlines processes, and delivers real business value.

entry.title: Re: inventory transition plan from company code to compan...
entry.content:
Try with the below options

Option-1
After doing 101, consider using movement type 344 which transfers the unrestricted stock to Quality. Once the Business decides, they are ready, this can be reversed via 343 to move back to unrestricted. This should work well for batch-managed materials and avoids blocked stock complications.

Option-2
Consider movement type 349 which would transfer from Unrestricted to Restricted. For reversal, you can use 348 and this will be useful if you want to prevent consumption but still allow visibility and planning.

Summary of movement types

entry.title: Re: Will the WBS PIR pick Order type from Production sche...
entry.content:
Check in material master Work Scheduling view, the Production Scheduling profile is assigned. Also, check whether the Production Scheduling Profile is assigned to Production Scheduler in OPKP.

To answer your question 'Do Strategy type affect this?', no, strategy type does affect this. Here's how:

  • Strategy type (e.g., 10, 20, 40) determines the requirement class
  • Requirement class determines the account assignment category
  • Account assignment category influences whether the system expects a WBS element, sales order, or cost center

If the strategy type doesn’t align with the WBS-based planning, the system may default to a different order type or ignore the PSP.

Next go to OPPE, and check whether MRP Group to Order type is mapped. Finally, in OPU5, check whether Planned Order profiles are configured for Plant, Order type and Production Scheduler.

entry.title: Re: How to Set Up Automatic Login in SAP
entry.content:
Hello,

You can use the SAP Webgui to log into the SAP system, create the VB scripts to access the URL and pass the user credentials.

VB script

______

set a = createobject("wscript.shell")
a.run "SAP WEBGUI URL"
wscript.sleep(2000)
a.sendkeys("User ID")
a.sendkeys chr(9)
wscript.sleep (2000)
a.sendkeys("password")
a.sendkeys "{Enter}"
wscript.quit

------------

Regards

Sriram

entry.title: Change Revenue Recognition key in Professional Services project
entry.content:
Hi, 

Our customer is running a S4 Cloud Public Edition and went live in june 2025. The customer is a shared service center using the professional services customer projects within theire system. They have two types of contracts: time & expense and periodic. During the implementation of the project, we haven't made any changes to the revenue recognition key being used — it's been the default one they currently have. Now, they’ve decided to change the key being used. I know this can be done via the app:
"Event-Based Revenue Recognition - Projects", but it looks like I have to update it per WBS element, one at a time.
Is there a way to perform a mass update for multiple WBS elements at once?

If the changes needs to be preformed in the app above is the most convinient way of handling it as follow: 
1. Enter billing element
2. Change revenue recognition key
3. Revalue

Or can we preform the changes and the rebooking in some other way? 

Thanks in advance, Sanne

entry.title: Re: How to use underdelivery tolerence in project stock r...
entry.content:
The underdelivery tolerance maintained in VD51 or in the Sales Order Shipping tab will work for standard Make-to-Order (MTO) strategy (e.g., Strategy 20), but I don't think, it will work automatically for Make-to-Project (MTP) scenarios.

Why because, the key differences between MTP and MTO are

  • MTP uses account assignment category Q (project stock), which changes how requirements are handled.
  • In MTP, the system treats the sales order requirement as project demand, and MRP plans it based on project stock availability, not sales order tolerance.
  • The underdelivery tolerance logic is not inherently linked to project stock planning, unless custom logic is added.

For your Requirement Class Z81, check whether '1' is maintained for Consumption indicator and Planning indicator. Still this may not prevent planned order creation unless the system sees the tolerance as a hard limit. Though you have correctly maintained the Lot-sizing Procedure with Under delivery tolerance ticked, this setup does not block planned order creation for project stock unless the system is explicitly told to do so.

To enforce underdelivery tolerance in MTP:

You may need to implement a BAdI or user exit in MRP logic (e.g., MD_CHANGE_MRP_DATA) to suppress planned order creation if available stock meets tolerance. This is especially relevant for project stock, where standard logic doesn’t apply tolerance checks.

entry.content:
GetEntity method will get called only when you know the key field values of the entity set.
ex : /sap/opu/odata/sap/ZSD_XXXX_XXXX_READ_SRV/InputParamSet('KeyField')?$format=json

When you call the InputParamSet directly, always GETENITYSET method would be triggered irrespective of the number of rows being returned (0 to n).

entry.title: Re: Change Revenue Recognition key in Professional Servic...
entry.content:
To my knowledge, as of now, SAP does not offer a standard mass update tool for revenue recognition keys across multiple WBS elements in the Event-Based Revenue Recognition – Projects app. The app is designed for individual updates, which can be time-consuming if you have many billing elements.

One alternative which SAP provides configuration tools that can help automate recognition key assignment going forward, but not retroactively. You can try with SSCUI 104054 – Define Replacement Rules for Recognition Keys which allows runtime replacement of recognition keys based on accounting principles. Useful if you want to switch keys dynamically without manual edits.

The other one is SSCUI 102517 – Derivation of Recognition Key for Projects both of which are mentioned in the SAP Help

entry.title: Re: How can I repair corrupt database
entry.content: If the database is inconsistent and unload fails, it’s likely the two affected tables have physical corruption in their data pages. SQL Anywhere doesn’t have many built-in repair options beyond dbvalid or unloading from a backup. Since you don’t have a backup, you’ll need to try a specialized recovery tool. Stellar Repair for MS SQL is made for repairing corrupted database files and can sometimes recover selected tables from damaged DBs, even if unload fails. It’s paid, but for production-critical tables it might be worth it. Otherwise, you could attempt to export unaffected rows with SELECT INTO before the engine hits the bad pages

entry.title: Re: Advanced Event Mesh - Partitioned Queues : One Queue for All
entry.content:
Hi Anuj,

You will still have restrictions; but if you design like this:

- Have a partitioned queue, consumed by multiple (let's say 5 consumers. They can be instance of the same app).

- depending on your work order number, it is always consumed by the same consumer(app instance). WorkOrder1->Consumer1 . WO2->C2 WO3->C5 etc.) regardless of the statuses.

- If your consumer knows to handle the statuses (it should know), then there wouldn't be  a problem.

- If smt. wrong happens for WO1-related messages, then C1 can handle it while C5 is still getting WO3 related messages. C1 of course should handle the problem of WO1 and continue getting these messages. 

Limit for this scenario is the number of consumers-partitions that you attach to the pipeline.

Baris

entry.title: Re: Difference in object list header data: previously / Y...
entry.content:
Check SAP note 3487322 which indicates the issue is about Serial Numbers. As recommended in that SAP note, you can run the report ZZ_ADJUST_ANZSN from SAP note 119719. If that is not the case, go through the below.

This error usually indicates a mismatch in the object list header data between the outbound delivery and the inbound delivery creation process. Specifically:

  • The object list (OL) in the outbound delivery contains a reference (e.g., /YY1114)
  • When SPED triggers the inbound delivery, SAP expects the same reference
  • If the reference changes or is missing, SAP throws IO308

This can happen due to changes in the delivery header data after PGI, or incorrect or missing configuration in output determination or inconsistent partner or plant assignments between supplying and receiving plants.

Check your output type whether routine 408 is assigned and ensure, the Partner Functions and Plants are assigned. Next go to VL03N, input that delivery reference and execute. From there go to Header > Status > Object List. Ensure no manual changes were made post-PGI. Of course, as you know, after PGI, most core logistics data (quantities, items, batch numbers, etc.) are locked. But SAP still allows changes to certain header-level or administrative fields, such as:

  • Texts (delivery header or item texts)
  • Output determination (e.g., adding or reprocessing output types like SPED)
  • Partner functions (in rare cases, if not fully locked)
  • Status fields (if updated via user exit or enhancement)
  • Object list entries (if manipulated via custom logic or interface)

entry.title: Re: How to activate safety relevance field on Task List -...
entry.content:
Hi @AnasShoaib 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

The scenario you reported typically happens In S/4HANA Cloud and it is due to standard system controls which could be either authorization, master data prerequisites, or product design limitations. SAP restricts some header fields for consistency and safety measure assignment may only be available at order level or based on master data linkage.

Here is what I recommend:

First, confirm scope item activation and business role assignments.

Then verify EHS safety measure master data and its release status.

Finally, double-check eligibility of your task list type and object assignment.

If everything is in order, I adivse you raise the issue with SAP support referencing the public cloud release notes, as some UI fields are standard-locked and require SAP's intervention.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Project Control - Intercompany Time recording
entry.content:
As per your screen shot, the error is "No prices could be determined for Object Activity Type A000/17101902/11". I presume, you should have maintained the data as

  • Activity Type: A000
  • Cost Center: 17101902
  • Period: 11

whereas, from your screen shot, I could see the 11 is maintained under Activity Type. I feel, this is the root cause of the issue.

entry.title: How to get single property from a nested structure using $select in Odata API Call
entry.content:
Hi

I am trying to read a single property from a nested entity using $select on a S4 Odata API using GET method. I can read the entire entity, that is working. However I just need to read one single property, but the $select is not working

e.g. /sap/opu/odata/sap/FAR_BS_ITM_REPROC_SRV/FinsPostingBSItemDspHeaders(BankStatementShortId='2711',BankStatementItem='1')?sap-client=200&select=BSItem 

This returns me the entire data from BSItem, however I just need to read 1 property from BSItem. I tried the following, but it did not work

entry.title: SAP tables categorized by module for SAP MM, PP, FICO, and PM
entry.content:
SAP MM (Material Management) Tables with Descriptions

  • MARA: Material Master - General Data (material type, basic attributes)

  • MAKT: Material Descriptions - Short texts/descriptions of materials

  • MARM: Material Master - Units of Measure

  • MARC: Material Master - Plant Data (plant-specific material info)

  • MARD: Material Master - Storage Location Data

  • MBEW: Material Valuation (valuation data per material)

  • EBAN: Purchase Requisition

  • EKKO: Purchase Order Header

  • EKPO: Purchase Order Items

  • MKPF: Material Document Header (goods movements)

  • MSEG: Material Document Items (line items of goods movements)

  • RBKP: Incoming Invoice Document Header (Invoice Verification)

  • RSEG: Incoming Invoice Document Items

  • BSIM: Secondary Index for Material Documents (Invoice Verification)

  • LFA1: Vendor Master General Data

SAP PP (Production Planning) Tables with Descriptions

  • CRHD: Work Center Header (work center master data)

  • MARC: Material Master - Plant Data (used also in PP)

  • MAST: Material to BOM Link (Bill of Materials associations)

  • STKO: BOM Header (Bill of Materials header)

  • STPO: BOM Item (Bill of Materials components)

  • PLKO: Task List Header (routing/task list master data)

  • PLPO: Task List Operations (operations within routings)

  • AFKO: Production Order Header Data (order master info)

  • AFPO: Production Order Items (production order line items)

  • RESB: Order Reservations / Dependent Requirements

  • MDKP: MRP Document Header Data (Material Requirements Planning)

  • PLAF: Planned Orders (planned production orders)

SAP FICO (Financial Accounting and Controlling) Tables with Descriptions

  • BKPF: Accounting Document Header

  • BSEG: Accounting Document Line Items

  • BSID: Customer Open Items (Secondary Index)

  • BSIK: Vendor Open Items (Secondary Index)

  • CSKS: Cost Center Master Data

  • COEP: CO Object Line Items (Costing line items by period)

  • KNA1: Customer Master Data

  • LFA1: Vendor Master Data

  • SKA1: G/L Accounts (Chart of Accounts)

  • REGUH: Settlement Data from Payment Program

SAP PM (Plant Maintenance) Tables with Descriptions

  • EQUI: Equipment Master Data (details of equipment)

  • EQKT: Equipment Short Texts (multilingual descriptions)

  • IFLOT: Functional Location Data (hierarchical location structures)

  • IHPA: Partners for Equipment / Functional Locations

  • AFIH: Maintenance Order Header (order master data for PM)

  • AFAB: Network Relationships (maintenance networks)

  • QMEL: Maintenance Notification Header (notifications of malfunctions)

  • PLKO: Task List Header (maintenance task lists)

  • MPLA: Maintenance Plans (planned maintenance schedules)

  • IMPT: Measuring Points (measurement data for equipment)

  • IMRG: Measurement Documents (records of measurements taken)

entry.title: Re: REFX Contract - Rental escalation with the Grading ..
entry.content:
Hi @Scnr 

Thank you for your question.

Please note that for your rental contracts in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the staged increases (10% after 3 years, then 20% over the next 2 years) can be set up directly in the Contract Conditions tab by using the Grading option. The system also defines that each step begins with its start date, percentage increase, and whether the calculation applies to the original base rent or the last graded rent Based on your requirements, the basis should be set to Original Value to ensure each increase is applied to your base unit price.

Be informed that lock-in periods are not controlled by a dedicated setting in the current standard version. However, you have the option to, define fixed validity periods in grading lines, restrict change authorizations during the lock-in term and track all updates using change reason codes.

Rental waivers during downturns can be added as separate waiver conditions for the applicable period, after which the contract will revert automatically to the graded rent.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Assigning Conditions and their Frequency to the Contract

Explaining Contract Conditions

entry.title: Re: How to rotate the form in 90 degrees in zebra printer
entry.content:
The command ^FWR (Field Reverse) rotates individual fields by 90 degrees in ZPL II, but it does not rotate the entire label and it requires manual repositioning of each field. The LZEBU3 device type does not support full-page rotation via SmartForms. Instead of ^FWR, use ^FW to set default orientation for all fields

Moreover, as per SAP note 1173046, Zebra Technologies' membership ended on 31 Dec 2024. Starting 1 Jan 2025, SAP will no longer maintain or update Zebra device types like YZB200/300. For any Zebra printer issues (including SmartForm rotation), you should contact Zebra Technologies directly. Reach out to Zebra’s SAP integration engineer (e.g., John Ramsey, as mentioned in the note).

However, you can try with Device Types YZB200 or YZB300 which support full label rotation and are more compatible with SmartForms

entry.title: Re: how to create non-posting tax code in sap b1 hana for...
entry.content:
Hi @nkdashpute 

Thank you for your quetion. Here are a few insights to consider.

In your current process, a Proforma Invoice can be used to show tax and total amounts for advance claims without creating any accounting entries. This is standard in SAP, Proformas are for display only and will not post to the journal.

SAP does not include a standard “tax code” that calculates but does not post in accounting for normal invoices, as tax postings are typically required for compliance. If you need this for Proforma purposes, the usual approach is to use a special billing or document type configured to suppress accounting postings while still showing tax in the output.

If your business process requires tax display but no postings in other document types, that would require either special configuration in account determination or a development enhancement and should always be checked against your local tax legislation.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Refx contract Activation is not possible due to warni...
entry.content:
SAP Note 3631508 confirms that:

  • Contracts involving foreign currency postings require a foreign currency role to be assigned
  • If this role is missing, activation fails—even if BP validity and posting terms are correct

Can you confirm by performing the below steps

Go to the contract header and verify if the currency is not local. If foreign currency is used, go to contract, navigate to the Partner Assignment tab, Add a BP with role TR0603 (Foreign Currency Role) or the equivalent in your system. Ensure the validity dates of this role cover the contract term (though you confirmed in the post, still wanted you to check this)

entry.title: Feasibility – Fixed HU per Material, Bin Replenishment & Direct PSA Consumption
entry.content:
We would like to clarify and/or configure the following business requirement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition – Warehouse Management:

  1. Dedicated HU for a Specific Material

    • Is it possible to assign a specific material to a fixed Handling Unit (HU), e.g., a pallet or container, so that this material is always packed/stored in the same HU type or even the same HU ID?

  2. Replenishment for that HU

    • Can we apply a replenishment strategy specifically for that HU (rather than generally for a bin), so that the HU is kept filled automatically and can be staged directly for production use?

  3. Direct Consumption from that HU in Production

    • If the HU is staged to the Production Supply Area (PSA), can we directly consume the material from this HU for a production order?

    • How is the HU identified in the consumption process?

  4. Pre-stocking PSA without a Production Order

    • Can we move and store a full HU with material in the PSA without having a production order, and then consume from it later whenever required for production?

entry.title: How to trigger navigation to a specific URL from a CAP action in Fiori Elements
entry.content:
I’m using SAP CAP (Node.js, OData V4) together with a Fiori Elements V4 ListReport/ObjectPage app. I have a bound action on an entity that’s triggered by a button labeled “Open Target”. When the user triggers this action, I want the app to navigate to a known Object Page route using an already prepared hash URL. I’d like to avoid adding client-side controller extensions or custom UI logic if possible. I tried sending a notification with a target URL from the CAP action, but the app does not navigate. Current behavior: The toast shows but there is no navigation, no errors. In the future, I would like to read the ID when a line is selected, the button is clicked, read the ID of the line, and then use this ID for navigation. But for now I wanted to test that with a fixed ID.
This is because it goes to a different service endpoint. my-service.js is located in /srv, where the CD files are stored.

// srv/my-service.js
module.exports = cds.service.impl(function () {
    let url = `/myapp/webapp/index.html#/TargetEntity(ID=38cf6b1a-2356-404e-b423-f4e21a6b7611,IsActiveEntity=true)`;

    req.notify({
      type: 'Success',
      message: 'Opening target…',
      target: url
    });

    return 'OK';
  });
});

entry.title: Re: Difference in object list header data: previously / Y...
entry.content:
Hello @Phuoc_Vo 

Please note that the SAP error IO308 indicates a mismatch between your stored header data and your newly processed data, which is often tied to serial number management.

This was potentially caused by, inconsistent or missing serial number records in tables like SER03, handling unit or custom process changes causing mismatched header info or recent transports/config changes affecting delivery or serial number processing.

Resolving this will require you to:

  1. Check SER03 for incorrect or temporary entries and correct them in your system.
  2. Compare your delivery header data with the related documents to find possible mismatches.
  3. Ensure to review your handling unit processes and potential recent changes that you might have made.
  4. You can also refer to SAP Notes 165566 which is related to serial number header errors

 

Please note that there is a lack of detailed resolution instructions and debugging the delivery processing based on serial number data and header contents is necessary.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

3487322 - error IO308 "Difference in object list header data:..." when processing a delivery

entry.title: Displaying CET Time in Sales Quotes Using Adobe LiveCycle Designer
entry.content:
Requirement: 
Display the sales quote PDF with the current date and time in CET, dynamically adjusting for daylight saving time, using Adobe LiveCycle Designer.

Challenges/Limitations:
We had a requirement to display CET date and time in our Sales Quote PDF template. Whenever we preview the sales quote PDF from SAP C4C system, it is launched with UTC time irrespective of the time zone in C4C user settings and Date Time field in our PDF is always displaying UTC time only. This is standard behavior, as the C4C system operates on the UTC time zone in the backend.

European clients operate within Central European Time (CET) and often require document timestamps to reflect their local time-both for regulatory alignment and ease of interpretation. Relying solely on UTC not only disrupts business workflows but may also result in customer dissatisfaction or compliance issues.

Understanding difference between UTC time zone and CET time zone:
The time difference between Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) and Central European Time (CET) is typically 1 hour. CET is 1 hour ahead of UTC. So, if it's 12:00 UTC, it would be 13:00 CET.

Keep in mind that during daylight saving time, Central European Summer Time (CEST) is 2 hours ahead of UTC so, if it’s 12:00 UTC, it would be 14:00 CEST. Daylight saving time usually starts on the last Sunday in March and ends on the last Sunday in October.

Solution:
To address this, a custom JavaScript code can be implemented in Date field. This script dynamically detects the UTC timestamp and converts it to CET (and CEST during daylight saving), ensuring that the PDF output reflects the correct local date and time.

Business Benefits:
Regional Compliance: Helps meet European regulatory requirements where local time documentation is mandated.
Customer Confidence: Builds trust by aligning with client expectations and reducing time-related misunderstandings.
Professionalism: Enhances the polish and accuracy of documents, reflecting positively on your brand.
Scalability: Offers a reusable solution for other regional time zone adjustments if needed in the future.

Steps to display CET time zone in Adobe Live Cycle Designer:
STEP 1:
Add a Date/Time Field in adobe LiveCycle Designer.

STEP 2:
Set the Object value as “Calculated Script”.

STEP 3:
On the initialize event update the the JavaScript code for converting UTC time to CET. The provided JavaScript code will automatically determine daylight saving and adjust the CET time accordingly.


Code Snippet:

//CET:--------------------------------------------
var LocalTime = new Date();  
this.rawValue = form1.TimeZoneDisplay.variables.CETtimefunction.condition(LocalTime);

//CETtimefunction:--------------------------------
function condition(getDate)
{
	var cetDateTime;
	try
	{
		var localTime = getDate;   
		// Get last Sunday of March
		var n = 25;  
		var dstStart;        
		while(n <=31)
		{
			// Day Light Saving Start Date
			dstStart = new Date(localTime.getFullYear(), 2, n);        // January = 0, Feb = 1, March = 2
			var day = dstStart.getDay(); 
			if(day == "0")          // Sunday = 0 , Monday = 1
			{           
				// Adjust for DST start time if necessary
				dstStart.setHours(2); // For example, DST starts at 2 AM 
				break;
			}
			n = n + 1;
		} 
		//Get last Sunday of October
		n = 25;
		var dstEnd;		
		while(n <=31)
		{
			// Day Light Saving End Date
			dstEnd = new Date(localTime.getFullYear(), 9, n); // January = 0, Feb = 1, March = 2,..., October = 9
			var day = dstEnd.getDay()  ;
			if(day == "0")          // Sunday = 0 , Monday = 1
			{           
				// Adjust for DST end time if necessary
				dstEnd.setHours(2); // For example, DST ends at 2 AM
				break;
			}
			n = n + 1;
		}	  
		// Calculate the offset between CET and UTC in minutes
		var cetOffsetInMinutes = 60;   
		
		// Normally Day light Saving time begins on last sunday of March and ends on last sunday of October
		if(localTime >= dstStart && localTime < dstEnd)  // if current date falls under day light saving time
		{
			cetOffsetInMinutes = 120;
		}  
		// Calculate the offset between local time and UTC
		var localOffsetInMinutes = localTime.getTimezoneOffset(); // returns 0 for UTC
	 
		// Calculate the total offset to adjust for CET
		var totalOffsetInMinutes = cetOffsetInMinutes - localOffsetInMinutes;
	 
		// Create a new Date object with the adjusted time
		var cetTime = new Date(localTime.getTime() + (totalOffsetInMinutes * 60000));
		var year = cetTime.getFullYear();
		var month = ("0" + (cetTime.getMonth() + 1)).slice(-2); // Pad month with leading zero
		var day = ("0" + cetTime.getDate()).slice(-2); // Pad day with leading zero
		var hours = ("0" + cetTime.getHours()).slice(-2);
		var minutes = ("0" + cetTime.getMinutes()).slice(-2);
		var seconds = ("0" + cetTime.getSeconds()).slice(-2);
		 
		cetDateTime = day + "." + month + "." + year + " " + hours + ":" + minutes + ":" + seconds; //UTC date time
		return cetDateTime;
	} // try ends
	
	catch(err)
	{ 
	}
}

RESULT:
After preview, the PDF is displaying CET time, and which is one hour ahead of UTC time. In time-of-day light saving the difference will be two hours.

Conclusion:
In summary, this enhancement bridges the gap between technical accuracy and client expectations by ensuring time-sensitive documents reflect local CET/CEST time. It not only strengthens communication and compliance but also demonstrates a thoughtful, client-first approach that sets your business apart. A small change - big impact.

entry.title: Re: Metric Dashboard availability in SAP Cloud Logging
entry.content:
Indeed, since eof July 2025 SAP Cloud Logging service now supports ingestion and visualization of SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime Container metrics.

Receive SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry runtime resource metrics (CPU, memory, ...) on NEW bindings or REBINDS.

To receive the metrics with user-provided services append ?drain-data=all to the syslog drain URL.

The new metrics can be investigated in "Container Metrics" dashboard under the "Four Golden Signals" in the navigation. The metrics are stored in OpenTelemetry compatible format and can be access via the metrics-otel-v1-* index pattern.

See: What's new announcement

entry.title: Re: How to Transport SAC Models and Import Jobs between T...
entry.content:
Hi Guido,

Unfortunately there is no connection over ride functionality in SAC.

When I looked at this we went with Option one, below.

One generically named connection, across both environments, which we migrated once and amended it to point to production.

The production re-pointing was a one time manual step and we didn't migrate the connection in future transports.

 

Connections

No ‘connections mapping’ or ‘dynamic connection switching’ concept available in SAC currently

 

Approach 1

  • Connection Movement via Package/ Export file from Development to Quality and Production landscapes
  • With simple change in connection details within the system as one-time manual step by basis team, which will keep connection ID same
  • Connection name in this approach will remains generic across the landscape like CONN_S4H_LIVE_ProjectName etc.

 

Approach 2

  • Create 3 connections in Development system one for each system (dev, qa, prod)
  • Switch the connection before transporting new model version
  • Switch the connection back after creating the transport unit
  • Connection Name can be System specific like DEVBW, QABW etc.

 

Approach 3 (Hybrid of both approaches which can be recommended)

  • Connection Movement via Package/ Export file from Development to Quality and Production landscapes
  • Rather than changing the connection configuration in Quality or Production landscapes, connection configuration can be edited in development landscape itself before moving to further systems.
  • Post transport of connections to further systems, edit back to original configuration i.e., development system as one-time manual step, which will keep connection unique ID same across the systems.
  • Connection name in this approach will remains generic like CONN_S4H_LIVE_ProjectName etc.

entry.title: Re: Complex Multi-Rater Performance Rating Overall Calculations in SAP SuccessFactors Integration Ce
entry.content:
Hi, 

Thank you for this example. 

We have a question regarding the functionality of competency evaluation. We have assigned competencies to different job positions, for example:

  • Employee 1 – Expert Position – Competency A – Expected Level 4
  • Employee 2 – Junior Position – Competency A – Expected Level 2

When we conduct the performance evaluation, we can display the expected level for the competency, so Let's assume a competency has 5 levels associated with the rating scale, just like the rating assigned to competencies. When evaluating Employee 1, if a level 2 is selected, there is a gap since level 4 is expected.

However, when evaluating Employee 2 for Competency A, if he is rated with a level 2, it means he meets the expectations.

In the system, when calculating the competency score, Employee 2 will receive a score of 2 for the competency, which means they meet the expectations for their position. Employee 1 will also receive a calculated score of 2, but in his case, he is not meeting the expected level.

So both will have the same evaluation score, but their results are not comparable.

Do you have any idea how to translate these results into expected outcomes and normalize them between employees?

Thank you very much.

entry.title: Re: Workflow not triggerd as per plan
entry.content:
SAP Public Cloud uses Flexible Workflow, and workflows are triggered based on preconditions. If multiple workflows apply to the same user or scenario, SAP checks them in order and triggers the first matching one.

So, if the ₹10,000 workflow is listed above the ₹50,000 auto-approval workflow, it might be getting triggered even when it shouldn’t.

Check the below areas

Go to Fiori App: Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders (App ID: F2872). Check the order of workflows and their preconditions. Ensure the ₹50,000 auto-approval workflow is listed above the ₹10,000 one

Review both workflows:

Does the ₹10,000 workflow have a condition like “User = X and Amount ≤ ₹10,000”?
Does the ₹50,000 workflow have “User = X and Amount ≤ ₹50,000” with no approval step?

If both match, SAP will trigger the first one that meets the condition. If the user is assigned to multiple roles or groups, she might be unintentionally matching the wrong workflow. Consider refining the preconditions to avoid overlap

entry.title: Re: Accounts not assigned under any group in Balance Shee...
entry.content:
Hi @SM1970 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

In ECC 6.0, GL account 1000 appears under “Accounts not assigned” in the balance sheet because it is not linked to the correct Financial Statement Version (FSV) item. To resolve the issue, you will need to assign the GL account to the correct item in the Financial Statement Version (FSV).

I suggest you carry out the following:

First, open the relevant FSV in SPRO and assign GL 1000 to the Accounts Payable node.

Then, ensure the GL master data is set up correctly as a liability or reconciliation account for vendors.

Additionally, if you are using New G/L with document splitting, check item category classification. Ensure GL Account 1000 is properly classified with the correct item category for document splitting. After changes, ensure to rerun the balance sheet to verify that the account displays under Accounts Payable.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to rotate the form in 90 degrees in zebra printer
entry.content: Based on your first try, I guess you don't understand well what are device types, drivers, printer languages, and how the OTF and ABAP List data are converted into the printer language. The PCL device type uses the HPL2 drivers (for printers configured with PCL language e.g. HP Laserjet), so it can't work on Zebra printers which only accept the ZPL printer language. Check the Zebra SAP notes and use a device type which uses a ZPL driver.

On inventory side, system will allow postings only in two periods

  • The current period
  • The previous period of the current period.

entry.title: 📦 Stock Transfer Posting in SAP GTM — A Hidden Gem in SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
Why This Blog?

If you work with SAP Global Trade Management (GTM) and haven’t explored Stock Transfer Posting (STP) via the Trading Execution Workbench (TEW), you’re not alone.

This feature has been available since SAP S/4HANA 1809, yet many users may still be unaware of its potential — especially when it comes to handling internal stock movements such as plant-to-plant or storage location transfers within GTM.

This blog highlights this functionality, along with examples and key logic to help you understand when and how to use it.

 

Background

SAP Global Trade Management (GTM) was originally developed to support companies engaged in the trading of physical goods — particularly those operating as trading houses or wholesale distributors. Its core purpose is to provide an integrated framework for managing the complete trading lifecycle, covering both sales and purchase contracts in a unified way.

In earlier years, many trading companies primarily operated on drop shipment models, where goods moved directly from supplier to customer. As a result, there was limited business need for internal stock transfers, and such scenarios weren’t a key focus area.

Over time, however, business models evolved — with many global traders now operating their own plants and warehouses to manage imports, consolidation, or compliance requirements. This shift created the need for system-supported internal movements — still within the context of trading contracts and the Trading Execution Workbench (TEW).

SAP addressed this business requirement by enhancing Trading Execution Workbench (TEW) to support Stock Transfer Posting (STP).

 

What’s Supported?

With Trading Execution Workbench (TEW), the following stock transfer scenarios are supported:

🏭Scenario 1: Transfer Between Plants

When needed:
Material is received in one plant (e.g., an import hub) but later moved to another for processing or dispatch.

Example:
A global trader receives 2,000 KG of sugar at Plant 0001 (Port Warehouse).
Later, 100 KG is moved to Plant 0002 (Packing Unit) to fulfil customer deliveries.

 

📦Scenario 2: Transfer Between Storage Locations

When needed:
Material is received in a general storage location (e.g., dock or receiving), but needs to be moved to another location such as quality check, staging, or picking area.

Example:
1,000 KG of chemical drums arrive at Storage Location 0001 (Receiving).
100 KG is moved to Storage Location 0002 (Quality Check) for inspection.

 

🔁Scenario 3: Batch-to-Batch Transfer

When needed:
Material is received under a system-generated batch, but the sales contract or customer expects it under a different batch (e.g., regulatory or customer-approved).

Example:
100 KG of pharmaceutical raw material is received under Batch 1.
To fulfil the sales order, it must be reassigned to Batch 2 (as expected by the customer).
This is handled through a batch transfer using TEW.

 

🧱 Scenario 4: WBS Element Transfer (Project Stock)

When needed:
Project stock needs to be reassigned between WBS elements — such as different project phases or cost objects.

Example:
500 KG steel beams are procured under WBS Element A.
Due to project rescheduling, 100 KG of them are reassigned to WBS Element B for another phase.

 

⛔Scenario 5: Cancellation of Stock Transfer Posting

When needed:
A previously executed stock transfer needs to be reversed — due to an incorrect destination, wrong quantity, or a change in downstream planning.

Example:
A stock transfer of 600 KG from Plant A to Plant B is executed but later cancelled because planning changed.
The quantity is reversed, and position updates are rolled back accordingly.

These scenarios are supported via Trading Execution Workbench (TEW) and follow GTM’s association logic, ensuring consistency and traceability across the process.

 

How the System Decides What to Transfer

Before a stock transfer is posted, the system checks how much material is available — referred to as the open quantity.

Key Definitions:

  • Open Quantity: The quantity available for transfer, calculated differently for plant vs. non-plant transfers.
  • Associated Quantity: Quantity already associated between a sales and purchasing document.
  • Un-associated Quantity: Quantity that is not yet associated.

🔒SAP ensures that associated quantities must be moved in full — they cannot be split.

 

🔄Transfer Rules (Simplified)

1️. Plant Transfers

System allows movement of:

  • ✔️Unassociated quantity, or
  • ✔️Associated quantity (only if no sales order exists for the associated sales contract), or
  • ✔️A combination of both

2️. Storage Location / Batch / WBS Element Transfers

System allows movement of:

  • ✔️Un-associated quantity, or
  • ✔️Associated quantity or
  • ✔️A combination of both

 

Why This Matters

Using Trading Execution Workbench (TEW) for internal stock transfers enables GTM users to:

  • Keep all stock movements integrated with trading contracts and positions
  • Avoid manual workarounds or steps outside GTM
  • Ensure accurate position and association management

 

Summary

Stock Transfer Posting via Trading Execution Workbench (TEW), brings valuable capabilities to GTM by enabling seamless internal stock movements across plants, storage locations, batches, and project stock.

While this functionality has been available for a while, it remains a highly relevant feature — especially for businesses that manage their own logistics networks alongside trading operations.

If your GTM processes involve internal material movements, this is a powerful tool to help keep everything contractually aligned, auditable, and efficient.

 

Over to You

Have you already been using Trading Execution Workbench (TEW) for stock transfers in GTM, or is this something you're just now exploring?

Whether you're applying it for plant transfers, batch reclassification, or WBS stock movements — we'd love to hear how it's helping your process.

💬Share your experiences, tips, or questions in the comments — and let’s continue to grow awareness of this powerful and flexible GTM capability!

entry.title: Re: Journey Through Data Migration in an SAP BRIM Implementation

Hi Satheesh - For creating both Solution Quote and Subscription Order, you can use FM CRM_ORDER_MAINTAIN with appropriate transaction type (PROCESS_TYPE), for example, standard type for solution quotation is SRVP). There are other follow-up FMs you may have to call to complete the creation process and handle errors (please check section Solution Quotation of this blog).

Also, post creation of subscription contracts/ provider contracts, BRIM system further distributes the data to relevant components for rating, billing etc. You can check the status of this distribution using transaction code FKKCC_PC_MON.

entry.title: Re: Advanced Event Mesh - Partitioned Queues : One Queue for All
entry.content:
Thanks again Baris - really appreciate your replies.

When I last checked, could only create 10 partitions. Since the number of Partitions are limited, I don’t think I will be able to use that in Prd.

Do you think using external data store (Redis or HANA DB) in conjunction with AEM would make sense? SCPI would consume AEM messages and before it processes that it checks the HANA DB for failures and if that order has failed in the past, it will not continue that order and push that in another queue (Failure Queue). The DB table will be updated with failed messages every time SCPU hits a failure for it to query in the next run. I could create two tables - one with only header info and other with full payload and when I query I only use the one with Header for quick turnaround.

The overhead is maintaining the DB tables.

I am not able to find any out of the box Solace options. I could be missing something.

Thanks again

-Anuj

entry.title: Re: Feasibility – Fixed HU per Material, Bin Replenishmen...
entry.content:
Hello @Shubham120798 

In S/4HANA Public Cloud  Edition WM

  • Fixed HU type based on material: Enabled via HU requirement settings and packing instructions.
  • Fixed HU ID by material: No, HU IDs are automatically assigned by the system.
  • HU-specific replenishment: Not standard; replenishment occurs at the bin level.
  • Direct consumption from HU in PSA: Yes, but it is quantity-based and tracked through bins.
  • Pre-stocking PSA without an order: Yes, performed via ad hoc or bin-to-bin warehouse tasks.

If HU-to-material binding or HU-level replenishment is necessary, consider using a custom CDS/app or submitting a Customer Influence request.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Where can I find documentation on changed process IDs...
entry.content:
Hi @Kuklik 

Yes, there have been reports that some internal process IDs for transactions related to electricity supply changes were adjusted by adding 50 to previous IDs for example start of delivery changing from 1010 to 1060 after June 6th. This aligns with system updates to accommodate the accelerated supplier change process.

However, note that SAP does not publicly document such internal process ID changes in the usual release notes or help portals in a straightforward way.

For any official SAP documentation on this update, I suggest you check the SAP Help Portal under latest release and legislative updates for Energy and Utilities sectors, or specific SAP Notes related to the June 6, 2025 regulatory changes.

One relevant source mention’s changes in the MaBiS process effective June 6, 2025, requiring the exclusive use of APERAK messages to confirm supplier switches within 24 hours, which indicates backend process updates but does not explicitly list process ID shifts.

To get exact documented process ID changes, I recommend raising a message with SAP Support referencing the June 6, 2025 legislation impact or checking with SAP’s legislative content support for Energy and Utilities.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
